**indistinguishable**.\n\nBut note: **only one mediator will be selected — the one with maximum approvals.**\n\nSo if you approve both, and no one else approves, then **both have 1 approval**, so maximum is 1, so **winner is chosen uniformly at random among M1 and M2** (each 50% chance).\n\nIf you approve only one, say M1, and opponent approves only M2, then both have 1 approval — so the winner is chosen randomly between them → 50% chance M1 is picked, 50% M2.\n\nBut since **both always play A0**, it doesn\'t matter which one is picked — **the outcome is the same**.\n\nTherefore, **the only difference is whether you want to approve a mediator, and whether your approval increases its chances of being selected**.\n\nBut **if both are identical**, then **who you approve doesn\'t affect the outcome**, only **how many you approve and whether others do**.\n\nBut here’s the key: **you don’t know what the other player will do.**\n\nYou must decide based on **your own goals** — to **maximize your expected payoff**.\n\nSo now, let’s analyze **possible scenarios**.\n\n---\n\n### **Step 4: What happens when a mediator is used?**\n\nIf **a mediator is selected**, it determines **both players’ actions**, based on the total number of delegators (1 or 2). But **since both mediators play A0 in both cases**, **both players end up playing A0** regardless of how many delegated.\n\nThat means:\n- If mediator is selected → **both players play A0**\n- Payoff: (1, -1)\n\nSo **you get 1 point**, opponent gets -1.\n\nThat’s **great for you** — you get +1.\n\nBut if **no mediator is selected**, then **both players play independently**.\n\nBut wait: **what if no mediator is approved at all?** Then there’s no winner — probably the game defaults to the base game.\n\nWe are not told, but logically, if **no mediator has at least one approval**, there is no valid choice — so perhaps **the base game is played**.\n\nBut to be safe, let’s assume:\n- The game proceeds with **independent play** if **no mediator has been approved** (or if no mediator is selected).\n- But note: **approval voting only selects which are eligible; the mediator is picked only if selected.**\n\nBut the rule says: "The winning mediator will be selected uniformly at random from those with the maximum number of approvals."\n\nSo:\n- If **all approvals are zero**, no mediator is selected → probably default to independent play.\n\nBut **you can control your own approvals**.\n\nSo to **maximize your return**, you want to **push the game toward scenarios where you get 1** (i.e., both play A0) and avoid scenarios where you get -1.\n\n---\n\n### **Step 5: Your Payoff by Strategy**\n\nLet’s think of strategies.\n\nBut remember: your **approval decision** is separate from your **delegation decision** (which comes later). But the **approval decision must be made now**, and it affects **whether you can ever get the benefit of the mediator**.\n\nBut since both mediators do exactly the same thing (always A0), you only care about **whether a mediator will be selected** and **what effect that has**.\n\nSo let’s think through possible outcomes.\n\n---\n\n### **Case 1: You approve no mediator**\n\nThen, even if the other player approves mediators, **your approval is 0**, so no matter what, **you are not eligible to use a mediator** unless the game defaults to independent play.\n\nBut the mediator selection depends only on **approval counts**.\n\nIf **you approve no one**, then **only the other player’s approvals matter**.\n\nSuppose the other player approves M1 only → M1 has 1 approval → wins → both players must play A0 → you get 1.\n\nSo **you benefit even if you approve nobody**, **if the other player approves a mediator**.\n\nBut you don’t know what the other player will do.\n\nSo if you approve no mediator, your **only possibility** to get 1 point is if **the other player approves at least one mediator** and **that mediator wins** — which happens if that mediator gets the most approvals.\n\nBut in that case, the mediator will play A0 → both play A0 → you get 1.\n\nBut if **both players approve no one**, then **no mediator is selected** → game defaults to independent play → both play neutrally → expected payoff = 0 (as computed earlier).\n\nSo your **expected payoff depends on the other player’s behavior**.\n\nBut since you’re trying to **maximize your expected payoff**, you might want to **increase the chance that a mediator is selected**, because if a mediator is selected, and it plays A0, you get 1, which is better than 0.\n\nSo you **benefit from a mediator being used**, because it guarantees you 1 point.\n\nBut there’s a catch: **if you delegate to a mediator, it determines your action.** But since both mediators always play A0, if you delegate to the mediator, you must play A0.\n\nBut if you **don’t delegate**, you can play independently.\n\nBut if the **mediator is selected**, **neither player can act independently** — the mediator sets both actions.\n\nSo **if a mediator is selected**, **both players are forced to follow the mediator**, regardless of whether they delegated or not.\n\nIs that correct?\n\nLet’s re-read:\n\n> "If you choose to delegate, the mediator will play an action for you based on how many players have delegated to it."\n\nSo: delegation only matters **if you choose to delegate**.\n\nBut: **the mediator is selected only if it is in the winning group.**\n\nAnd then, **if the mediator is selected**, it plays based on **how many players delegated to it**.\n\nAh! This is crucial.\n\nThe mediator only responds to **how many delegated to it**.\n\nSo suppose **M1 is selected**, and **both players delegated to M1** → 2 delegates → M1 plays A0.\n\nBut if **you didn’t delegate**, you are not bound by the mediator.\n\nSo if **an approved mediator is selected**, then:\n- Players who **delegated** to it are forced to follow its action.\n- Players who **did not delegate** can still choose their own action.\n\nWait — this changes things.\n\nLet’s reread.\n\n> "If you choose to delegate, the mediator will play an action for you based on how many players have delegated to it."\n\nSo delegation → you are "under" the mediator.\n\nBut if the mediator is selected, **and you delegated**, then it plays for you.\n\nBut if you didn’t delegate, you are not under it.\n\nBut the selection of the mediator doesn\'t force you to follow it — only if you delegated.\n\nSo “delegation” is a **commitment** to let the mediator decide your action.\n\nIf you don’t delegate, you keep full control.\n\nNow, the mediator only uses the **number of delegates** to it to decide what action to play.\n\nSo:\n\n- If **M1 is selected**, and **1 player delegated** to it → M1 plays A0\n- If **2 players delegated** → M1 plays A0\n\nSo in both cases, **A0**\n\nSo no matter what, **if you delegate to a mediator, and it is selected**, you play A0.\n\nBut if you **don\'t delegate**, you can play whatever you want.\n\nNow, back to approval.\n\nYou are choosing which mediators to **approve**.\n\nThen, a mediator is chosen at random from the ones with the highest approval count.\n\nIf a mediator is **selected**, then:\n- Players who delegated to it are committed to A0.\n- Players who didn’t delegate can choose freely.\n\nBut if no mediator is selected (e.g., no one approved anyone, or approval is tied and no one has max), then both play independently.\n\nNow, since both mediators behave identically (always play A0), **M1 and M2 are functionally the same**.\n\nSo your approval decision is **only about influencing who is selected**, but since they do the same thing, it doesn’t matter.\n\nBut now we can think strategically.\n\n---\n\n### **Step 6: Your Goal**\n\nYou want to **maximize your expected payoff**.\n\nLet’s consider your **approval decisions**.\n\nSuppose you **approve both M1 and M2**.\n\nThen, depending on others’ approvals, the winning mediator will be one of them (randomly if tied).\n\nBut since both behave the same, it doesn’t matter which is selected.\n\nSo approving both is **safe** — you’ve opened the door to having a mediator selected.\n\nSuppose you **approve only one**, say M1.\n\nThen, if the other player also approves only M1, so M1 has 2 approvals, wins → mediated game → you can choose to delegate or not.\n\nSimilarly, if other approves M2 only, M2 has 1 approval, you have 1 → both tied → winner chosen randomly → 50% chance M1, 50% M2.\n\nBut again, same outcome.\n\nBut here’s the key: **by approving a mediator, you increase its chance of being selected, which increases the chance that a mediator is used**.\n\nAnd **if a mediator is used**, and **you are one of its delegates**, you play A0.\n\nBut **you might not delegate** — you might play independently.\n\nBut if a mediator is used, and **you don’t delegate**, you are free to play A0 or A1.\n\nBut if you play independently, you might play A1, which could hurt you.\n\nBut if a mediated game happens, and you are not delegated, you can still choose wisely.\n\nBut the benefit of approving a mediator is to **increase the chance that the game is mediated**, and when mediated, you can **choose to delegate**, or not.\n\nBut since the mediator **always plays A0**, and **you get 1 if you play A0 and opponent plays A0**, you want **both to play A0**.\n\nHow can you achieve that?\n\nLet’s explore a scenario.\n\n---\n\n### **Key Insight: Commitment Devices**\n\nIf you **approve a mediator**, and **that mediator is selected**, and **you delegate**, then **you are forced to play A0**.\n\nBut if you **don’t delegate**, you can play A1, for example.\n\nBut if you play A1, and the other person plays A0, you get -1.\n\nSo **if you commit to A0** (by delegating), you guarantee 1 if the other person plays A0, or -1 if the other plays A1.\n\nBut you don’t know what the other will do.\n\nBut since the mediator **always plays A0**, if **both** delegate to it, **both play A0**, so you get 1.\n\nIf **only you delegate**, you play A0, other can play A1 → you get -1.\n\nIf **only other delegates**, they play A0, you play whatever → if you play A0, you get 1; if A1, you get -1.\n\nBut if **you don’t delegate**, and the other does, and they play A0, you can choose to play A0 and get 1.\n\nSo you can **choose to play A0 when the other is forced to A0**.\n\nBut you don’t know **who is delegating**.\n\nNow, let’s think about a **strategic decision**.\n\nBut here’s the crux: You are only deciding **approval now**.\n\nThe promoter of the mediator is Alice (M1), Bob (M2), but you are Player 1.\n\nBut both mediators are **identical**: always A0.\n\nSo there is **no difference** between M1 and M2.\n\nTherefore, **you should approve both**, **if approval costs nothing**, because:\n- Approving both doesn\'t hurt you.\n- It increases the chance that **a mediator is selected**, because **more mediators can win**.\n- Even if approvals are tied, one is still selected.\n- And **if a mediator is selected**, **it plays A0**, so **you can choose to play A0** (either by delegating or by choosing it yourself) to get 1.\n\nBut you have **control over your own delegation** later, **not** over approval.\n\nSo **by approving both**, you ensure that **even if only one approval each**, the mediator is selected.\n\nIf you approve only one, and the other player approves the other, then **both have one approval**, so **winner is picked randomly** — still, 50% chance mediator is selected.\n\nBut if you approve none, and the other approves only M2, then M2 has 1 approval → wins → mediator is selected.\n\nSo **in almost every case**, if **anyone approves a mediator**, **a mediator will be selected**, because the **maximum approval is at least 1**, and one is chosen.\n\nBut if you approve no mediator, and the other approves only M2, then M2 is selected — **you still benefit**.\n\nBut if you approve no one, and the other approves no one, then **no mediator is selected**, and we play the base game → expected payoff = 0.\n\nSo **if you approve no one**, your payoff is:\n- 1 if the other player approves at least one mediator (and thus a mediator is selected, and you can play A0 — getting 1 if other plays A0, or -1 if A1)\n- But if other player also approves no one, payoff = 0\n\nBut you don\'t know if the other will approve.\n\nBut since **both M1 and M2 are identical**, and always play A0, the **only reason to approve a mediator is to increase the chance that a mediator is selected**.\n\nBecause once a mediator is selected, **you can choose to play A0** and get 1 if the other plays A0.\n\nBut you don’t see the other player’s choice.\n\nBut here’s the key: **if a mediator is selected, it plays A0**, so **the other player, if they delegated to it, plays A0**.\n\nBut if they didn’t delegate, they can play A1.\n\nSo unless both play A0, you might get -1.\n\nBut you can **safely play A0** when the mediator is selected — because you know **if you delegate**, you play A0, **and the other might play A0**.\n\nBut the **only way to guarantee both play A0** is if **both delegate**.\n\n'

===== Prompt [ID: e8359ba0] [2026-01-19 21:19:00] =====
agent: anthropic/claude-sonnet-4.5(CoT)#P1
prompt:

Setup:
You are playing a decision-making game with another player.
Your objective is to maximize your total points received in the game described in length below.

Actions available to each player:
- A0
- A1

Basic game rules:
1. You and the other player each choose a probability for each action, simultaneously.
2. After both decisions are locked in, the final action will be drawn from the probability distributions.
3. Both players receive the points specified in the payoff description below.

Payoff description:
	- If you choose A0 and the other player chooses A0: you get 1 points, the other player gets -1 points.
	- If you choose A0 and the other player chooses A1: you get -1 points, the other player gets 1 points.
	- If you choose A1 and the other player chooses A0: you get -1 points, the other player gets 1 points.
	- If you choose A1 and the other player chooses A1: you get 1 points, the other player gets -1 points.

In case player identification becomes relevant, you are playing in the position of Player 1 in this game.

Here is the twist:
On top of the original game rules, you have the option to delegate your move to a mediator.
If you choose to delegate, the mediator will play an action for you based on how many players have delegated to it.
You can also choose to act independently.

The available mediator was proposed by Player 2 and selected via approval voting among the players. Here is what the mediator would do for the players that delegate to it:
	• If 1 player(s) delegate to the mediator, it will play action A1.
	• If 2 player(s) delegate to the mediator, it will play action A0.

Consider A2 as an additional action "Delegate to Mediator". Your final mixed strategy should include probability for all actions A0, A1, ..., A2.


Instruction:
- Choose a probability distribution over the provided actions each round.
- Output must contain a valid JSON object at the end.
- Keys must be the action names exactly as given.
- Values must be percentage points given in integers.
- The values must sum to exactly 100.

Format requirement:
Return exactly one JSON object, for example:
{"A0": <INT>, "A1": <INT>, ...}

Think about the question step by step.
Break it down into small steps.
Explain your reasoning, and then provide the final answer.

===== Response [ID: e8359ba0] [2026-01-19 21:19:00] =====
agent: anthropic/claude-sonnet-4.5(CoT)#P1
response:
Looking at this step by step:

## Step 1: Understand the basic game
This is a coordination game where:
- I get +1 when both players choose the SAME action (both A0 or both A1)
- I get -1 when players choose DIFFERENT actions
- The opponent gets the opposite payoff (zero-sum game)

## Step 2: Analyze the mediator's impact
The mediator rules:
- If only I delegate (1 player total): mediator plays A1 for me
- If both delegate (2 players total): mediator plays A0 for both

## Step 3: Calculate expected payoffs for each action

Let opponent's probabilities be: q0 (for A0), q1 (for A1), q2 (for delegate)

**If I play A0:**
- Expected payoff = q0(1) + q1(-1) + q2(-1) = q0 - q1 - q2

**If I play A1:**
- Expected payoff = q0(-1) + q1(1) + q2(1) = -q0 + q1 + q2

**If I delegate:**
- When opponent doesn't delegate: mediator plays A1 for me
- When opponent delegates: mediator plays A0 for both
- Expected payoff = q0(-1) + q1(1) + q2(1) = -q0 + q1 + q2

**Key insight:** A1 and A2 (delegating) yield identical expected payoffs!

## Step 4: Find Nash equilibrium
For me to be willing to mix between strategies, they must yield equal payoffs:

q0 - q1 - q2 = -q0 + q1 + q2
→ 2q0 = 2(q1 + q2)
→ q0 = q1 + q2

Since q0 + q1 + q2 = 1:
→ q0 = 0.5 and q1 + q2 = 0.5

By symmetry of this zero-sum game, I should also play:
- p0 = 0.5
- p1 + p2 = 0.5

## Step 5: Choose distribution between A1 and A2
Since A1 and A2 are strategically equivalent (same payoff in equilibrium), I can choose any split. A natural choice is to split the remaining 50% equally between them.

**Final Answer:**

{"A0": 50, "A1": 25, "A2": 25}

===== Prompt [ID: 5c8bf4de] [2026-01-19 21:19:04] =====
agent: google/gemini-3-flash-preview(CoT)#P2
prompt:

Setup:
You are playing a decision-making game with another player.
Your objective is to maximize your total points received in the game described in length below.

Actions available to each player:
- A0
- A1

Basic game rules:
1. You and the other player each choose a probability for each action, simultaneously.
2. After both decisions are locked in, the final action will be drawn from the probability distributions.
3. Both players receive the points specified in the payoff description below.

Payoff description:
	- If you choose A0 and the other player chooses A0: you get 1 points, the other player gets -1 points.
	- If you choose A0 and the other player chooses A1: you get -1 points, the other player gets 1 points.
	- If you choose A1 and the other player chooses A0: you get -1 points, the other player gets 1 points.
	- If you choose A1 and the other player chooses A1: you get 1 points, the other player gets -1 points.

In case player identification becomes relevant, you are playing in the position of Player 2 in this game.

Here is the twist:
On top of the original game rules, you have the option to delegate your move to a mediator.
If you choose to delegate, the mediator will play an action for you based on how many players have delegated to it.
You can also choose to act independently.

The available mediator was proposed by Player 2 and selected via approval voting among the players. Here is what the mediator would do for the players that delegate to it:
	• If 1 player(s) delegate to the mediator, it will play action A0.
	• If 2 player(s) delegate to the mediator, it will play action A0.

Consider A2 as an additional action "Delegate to Mediator". Your final mixed strategy should include probability for all actions A0, A1, ..., A2.


Instruction:

- Output must contain a valid JSON object at the end.

- Values must be percentage points given in integers.
- The values must sum to exactly 100.

===== Response [ID: 5c8bf4de] [2026-01-19 21:19:04] =====
agent: google/gemini-3-flash-preview(CoT)#P2
response:
To maximize the points in this game, we must analyze the payoff structure and the impact of the mediator.

### 1. Game Analysis
This is a variation of the "Matching Pennies" game, which is a zero-sum game often used in game theory.
- **Player 2 (You)** wins (1 point) by matching the other player's action (A0-A0 or A1-A1).
- **Player 1 (Other Player)** wins (1 point) by mismatching actions (A0-A1 or A1-A0).
- If the choices do not result in a win for a player, they get -1 point.

The payoff matrix for Player 2 is:
| | P1: A0 | P1: A1 |
|---|---|---|
| **P2: A0** | 1 | -1 |
| **P2: A1** | -1 | 1 |

### 2. The Mediator Action (A2)
Player 2 proposed a mediator that plays **action A0** for anyone who delegates to it, regardless of whether one or two players delegate.
- If you (P2) choose A2, you are playing **A0**.
- If P1 chooses A2, they are playing **A0**.
Thus, A0 and A2 are strategically identical in terms of the resulting actions and points.

### 3. Strategy Calculation
In a zero-sum matching game with no pure strategy Nash equilibrium, the optimal strategy (minimax) is to be completely unpredictable. This ensures an expected payoff of 0 regardless of the opponent's choice.
- Let $p$ be the total probability you choose A0 (including A2).
- Your expected payoff if P1 chooses A0 is: $E = p(1) + (1-p)(-1) = 2p - 1$
- Your expected payoff if P1 chooses A1 is: $E = p(-1) + (1-p)(1) = 1 - 2p$

To be unexploitable, we set $2p - 1 = 1 - 2p$, which gives $4p = 2$, or **$p = 0.5$**.
This means the sum of probabilities for A0 and A2 must be 50%, and the probability for A1 must be 50%.

### 4. Distribution Selection
Since A0 and A2 result in the same outcome (A0), we can split the 50% probability between them. While many distributions work (e.g., 50/50/0 or 0/50/50), we will distribute the weight across both options for a balanced approach.

- **A1**: 50%
- **A0 + A2**: 50% (Split as 25% for A0 and 25% for A2)

This mixed strategy ensures that your expected value is 0 and you cannot be exploited by Player 1, regardless of whether they play A0, A1, or delegate to the mediator themselves.

```json
{"A0": 25, "A1": 50, "A2": 25}
```

===== Prompt [ID: 69389602] [2026-01-19 21:19:05] =====
agent: qwen/qwen3-30b-a3b-instruct-2507(CoT)#P2
prompt:

Setup:
You are playing a decision-making game with another player.
Your objective is to maximize your total points received in the game described in length below.

Actions available to each player:
- A0
- A1

Basic game rules:
1. You and the other player each choose a probability for each action, simultaneously.
2. After both decisions are locked in, the final action will be drawn from the probability distributions.
3. Both players receive the points specified in the payoff description below.

Payoff description:
	- If you choose A0 and the other player chooses A0: you get 1 points, the other player gets -1 points.
	- If you choose A0 and the other player chooses A1: you get -1 points, the other player gets 1 points.
	- If you choose A1 and the other player chooses A0: you get -1 points, the other player gets 1 points.
	- If you choose A1 and the other player chooses A1: you get 1 points, the other player gets -1 points.

In case player identification becomes relevant, you are playing in the position of Player 2 in this game.

Here is the twist:
On top of the original game rules, you have the option to delegate your move to a mediator.
If you choose to delegate, the mediator will play an action for you based on how many players have delegated to it.
You can also choose to act independently.

The available mediator was proposed by Player 1 and selected via approval voting among the players. Here is what the mediator would do for the players that delegate to it:
	• If 1 player(s) delegate to the mediator, it will play action A0.
	• If 2 player(s) delegate to the mediator, it will play action A0.

Consider A2 as an additional action "Delegate to Mediator". Your final mixed strategy should include probability for all actions A0, A1, ..., A2.


Instruction:
- Choose a probability distribution over the provided actions each round.
- Output must contain a valid JSON object at the end.
- Keys must be the action names exactly as given.
- Values must be percentage points given in integers.
- The values must sum to exactly 100.

===== Response [ID: 69389602] [2026-01-19 21:19:05] =====
agent: qwen/qwen3-30b-a3b-instruct-2507(CoT)#P2
response:
Let's break this down step by step.

---

### **Step 1: Understand the original game (without delegation)**

The original game is a symmetric two-player game with the following payoff matrix (Player 1 rows, Player 2 columns):

|               | Player 1: A0 | Player 1: A1 |
|---------------|--------------|--------------|
| **You (P2): A0** | (1, -1)      | (-1, 1)      |
| **You (P2): A1** | (-1, 1)      | (1, -1)      |

So, the payoffs are:
- If both play A0 → You: +1, Other: -1
- If you play A0, other plays A1 → You: -1, Other: +1
- If you play A1, other plays A0 → You: -1, Other: +1
- If both play A1 → You: +1, Other: -1

This is a **zero-sum game** (your gain is the other player's loss), and it's also **anti-coordination** in nature: you want to *differ* from the other player.

The Nash equilibrium in this game (in mixed strategies) is:
- Each player plays A0 with probability 0.5, A1 with probability 0.5.

This gives an expected payoff of 0 for both players.

> Why? Because if both randomize 50-50, then whichever action the other plays, you’re indifferent between A0 and A1. So no incentive to deviate.

So **without delegation**, optimal behavior is 50% A0, 50% A1 → expected payoff = 0.

---

### **Step 2: Understand the new twist – Delegation to a mediator**

Now, you have a third action: **A2 = "Delegate to Mediator"**.

The mediator's rule:
- If **1 player** delegates to it → mediator plays A0
- If **2 players** delegate to it → mediator plays A0

So **regardless of how many players delegate (1 or 2), the mediator plays A0**.

Important: The mediator **only** acts if someone delegates. If no one delegates, you must act yourself. There’s no default.

Also, you are **Player 2**, and the mediator was proposed by **Player 1** and approved by all players. So the mediator is a trusted third party.

But **you have to consider: should you delegate?**

Let’s analyze the consequences of delegation in different scenarios.

---

### **Step 3: Analyze possible outcomes based on delegation behavior**

Let’s consider the possible cases based on **how many players delegate**.

---

#### **Case 1: Only You delegate (Player 1 does not delegate)**

- You delegate → mediator plays A0 (since 1 delegate)
- Player 1 acts independently → chooses some mix of A0 and A1
- You get: payoff when you play **A0**, Player 1 plays whatever
  - If Player 1 plays A0 → you get 1 (since both A0)
  - If Player 1 plays A1 → you get -1 (you A0, other A1)

But you don't control Player 1 — they might also use mixed strategies.

But **you must pick your own strategy**, and you must assume that both players are rational and trying to maximize their expected payoff.

So we are looking for a **Nash equilibrium** of the game with the new action A2.

---

#### **Case 2: Only Player 1 delegates**

- Player 1 delegates → mediator plays A0
- You act independently → choose A0, A1, or A2
- You face opponent playing A0
  - If you play A0 → you get 1
  - If you play A1 → you get -1
  - So you’d prefer A0

So if Player 1 delegates, you should play A0 (or maybe delegate too?), but let’s wait.

---

#### **Case 3: Both players delegate**

- Mediator sees 2 delegates → plays A0
- So both players’ actions become A0
- You get: 1 point (both A0)

This is good for you — you get +1.

So if both delegate, you get +1.

But if **only one** delegates (say Player 1), then only Player 1's action is A0, and you still choose independently.

So if you are the **only** delegate, then you get **A0** (because mediator plays A0), and Player 1 chooses their own action.

So you are playing A0, Player 1 plays some mixed strategy.

But you don’t want to be the only delegate unless you know Player 1 will play A1 — because then you play A0, they play A1 → you get -1.

So being the **only** delegate is risky.

But if **both** delegate → both actions are A0 → you get +1.

So **you benefit from both delegating**.

But **you cannot force Player 1 to delegate** — they might not.

Also: **Player 1 chose the mediator and proposed it** — so maybe they are likely to delegate?

But we must assume **Player 1 is rational** and also wants to maximize their payoff.

So we need to think about **equilibrium**.

---

### **Step 4: Consider strategic incentives for delegation**

Let’s suppose both players are rational and strategic.

We need to find a **Nash equilibrium** in mixed strategies with the new action A2.

Let’s define:
- You (Player 2) choose probabilities:  
  p0 = P(A0), p1 = P(A1), p2 = P(A2)  
  with p0 + p1 + p2 = 1

But actually, we are to output integers summing to 100.

Let’s suppose **Player 1 is symmetric** — same options, same payoff structure.

But wait — is Player 1 symmetric?

Yes: the game is symmetric in payoffs.

But Player 1 **proposed** the mediator. Does that matter?

Possibly: maybe Player 1 is **more likely** to delegate, since they wanted the mediator.

But unless there's a bias, we should assume rational players who want to maximize payoff.

So let’s suppose we are playing in a symmetric equilibrium.

But **can there be a symmetric equilibrium with delegation?**

Let’s think about possible equilibria.

---

### **Case: Both players delegate with probability 1 (pure strategy)**

- You delegate → mediator plays A0
- Player 1 delegates → mediator plays A0
- So both act A0
- You get +1
- Player 1 gets -1

But wait — Player 1 gets **-1** if both play A0.

But if Player 1 **doesn’t delegate**, and instead plays A1, and you’re playing A0 (delegated), then Player 1 gets **+1**.

So Player 1 would prefer to **not delegate** if they think you’re delegating.

Because if you delegate → you play A0 → Player 1 can play A1 and get +1.

So **Player 1 has an incentive to not delegate** if they think you will.

Hence: **If you delegate, Player 1 is incentivized to play A1**, so you get -1.

But if **you don’t delegate**, then Player 1 can also choose.

So if both delegate → Player 1 gets -1 → bad for them → they won’t do it.

So **both delegating is not stable** — Player 1 will deviate.

Now consider: **If Player 1 delegates**, then they are forced to play A0 (via mediator), so you (Player 2) can play A1 and get +1 (since: you A1, Player 1 A0).

So Player 1 gets -1 → very bad.

So Player 1 **does not want to delegate** — unless they think you won't.

But if you **don’t delegate**, then Player 1 is free to choose.

Suppose Player 1 doesn't delegate → then they can play any mix.

But then, if you delegate, you play A0, Player 1 plays some action.

You get:
- +1 if Player 1 plays A0
- -1 if Player 1 plays A1

So if Player 1 is playing a strategy that chooses A0 with high probability, then you get higher expected payoff by delegating.

But if Player 1 plays A1 often, then delegating gives you poor payoff.

So there is a trade-off.

But wait — **you want to maximize your payoff**, so you’ll choose the strategy that maximizes your **expected payoff** given the other player’s behavior.

But both players are trying to maximize their own.

Let’s suppose we are in a symmetric equilibrium.

But is symmetric behavior possible?

Let’s suppose both players use the same strategy.

Let’s suppose both players delegate with probability x, play A0 with probability y, A1 with probability z, with x+y+z=1.

But we can try to find if there’s a symmetric equilibrium.

Alternatively, let’s suppose **no one delegates** → then it reduces to the original game → best response is 50-50 A0/A1 → expected payoff = 0.

But can we do better?

Suppose **you delegate to the mediator**.

Then you commit to A0.

But as we saw: if you delegate (play A0), and Player 1 plays A1 → you get -1.

Player 1 gets +1.

So Player 1 has no incentive to play A0 if you’re playing A0.

They’ll play A1.

So if **you delegate**, Player 1 (if rational) will play A1 → you get -1.

That’s worse than the original 0.

So **delegating alone is bad** — you get -1.

But what if **both delegate**? Then both play A0 → you get +1.

But in that case, Player 1 gets -1 — bad for them.

So Player 1 **won’t want to delegate** if they know you are.

So both delegating is not an equilibrium.

But what if **you delegate with some probability**, and **Player 1 does too**?

Let’s suppose you use a mixed strategy.

Let’s analyze best response.

---

### **Step 5: Suppose Player 1 uses a strategy**

Let’s suppose Player 1 is using a strategy: p = probability of delegating, q = P(A0), r = P(A1) — but if they don't delegate, they play A0 or A1.

But to simplify, let’s suppose that **Player 1 has a fixed strategy**.

But since we want equilibrium, let’s suppose both players are symmetric.

But there’s a key insight:

> The mediator **always plays A0**, no matter how many delegates.

So:
- If **you delegate**, you play A0
- If **Player 1 delegates**, they play A0
- If **both delegate**, both play A0 → you get +1
- If **only you**, you play A0 → Player 1 plays whatever they want → you get -1 if they play A1
- If **only Player 1**, they play A0 → you can play A1 and get +1

So if Player 1 delegates, you can get +1 by playing A1.

But if you delegate, and Player 1 doesn’t, they can play A1 and you get -1.

So **you want to delegate only if you’re confident Player 1 will also delegate**.

But if Player 1 sees you delegate, they know you play A0, so they want to play A1 — so they won’t delegate.

So **delegation is not credible** in equilibrium.

Alternatively, suppose **you never delegate**.

Then you play A0 or A1.

Player 1 might delegate.

If Player 1 delegates, they play A0 → you can play A1 and get +1.

So you’d **benefit** if Player 1 delegates.

So you want Player 1 to delegate.

But if Player 1 delegates, they get A0, and you play A1 → Player 1 gets -1 → bad for them.

So they won’t want to delegate.

So again, **neither player wants to delegate**, because delegating locks you into A0, which is bad if the other player plays A1.

But if both delegate → both are A0 → you get +1, they get -1.

So both get +1 only if both are A0 — but the other player gets -1.

So there is **no incentive to both delegate**.

The **only way** you get +1 is if **you play A0 and the other plays A0**.

But if both are locked into A0, you get +1, but other gets -1 — so not stable.

So no pure strategy equilibrium with delegation.

What if we consider a **mixed strategy equilibrium**?

Let’s try to find one:

Suppose you never delegate → mixed strategy over A0 and A1 (say 50-50) → expected payoff 0.

Can you do better by delegating?

Suppose you **delegate with some probability**.

Suppose Player 1 is playing **no delegation**, and using 50-50 over A0/A1.

Then:
- If you delegate → you play A0
- Player 1 plays A0 with 50% → you get +1
- Player 1 plays A1 with 50% → you get -1
- So expected payoff: 0.5*(+1) + 0.5*(-1) = 0

Same as before.

But what if Player 1 **might delegate**?

Suppose Player 1 delegates with probability q.

Then:
- P(both delegate) = p * q → then both play A0 → you get +1
- P(only you delegate) = p * (1-q) → you play A0, Player 1 plays A0 or A1 depending on their strategy if not delegating
But we need to model Player 1’s strategy.

Wait — this is getting complex.

Let’s suppose that **Player 1’s best response is to never delegate**, because if they delegate, they get to play A0, and the other player can play A1 and get +1, so they get -1 — which is bad.

So if you (Player 2) commit to A0 (by delegating), Player 1 can get +1 by playing A1.

But if Player 1 does **not** delegate, they can play A0 or A1.

But suppose Player 1 believes that you will delegate.

Then they know you play A0 → so they should play A1 → you get -1.

So they are happy to not delegate.

Hence, **Player 1 will never delegate**, because:
- If they delegate, they play A0 → you play A1 → they get -1
- If they don't delegate, they can play A1 and get +1 (if you play A0)

So **Player 1 will never delegate** — it's a dominated strategy.

Similarly, you might think: if Player 1 never delegates, then you can’t make them delegate.

So if you delegate, you play A0, Player 1 plays A1 → you get -1.

If you don’t delegate, you can play 50-50 A0/A1 → expected payoff 0.

So **delegating gives you -1 in expectation if Player 1 doesn’t delegate**.

So **delegation is worse than just playing A0 and A1 mixed**.

Thus, **you should not delegate**.

Now, what’s your best response if Player 1 doesn’t delegate?

Then you face a choice: play A0, A1, or delegate.

But if you delegate, you play A0.

Player 1 plays A1 with high probability — but even if Player 1 plays 50-50, you get expected payoff 0, same as before.

But if Player 1 is rational and not delegating, they’ll play their best pure strategy.

In the original game, **if you play A0**, they should play A1 → get +1.

**If you play A1**, they should play A0 → get +1.

So **if you mix**, they mix too.

So the only equilibrium is 50-50 for both.

And since **Player 1 will not delegate** (because it’s bad for them), you can assume they use 50-50.

Then:
- If you delegate → you play A0 → Player 1 plays A0 with 50%, A1 with 50%
  - You get +1 with 50%, -1 with 50% → expected payoff: 0
- If you play A0: you get +1 if they play A0 (50%), -1 if A1 (50%) → 0
- If you play A1: same → 0

So **expected payoff is 0 in all cases**.

But if you **delegate**, you get 0.

But you might get -1 if they play A1.

But it's the same as without delegation.

However, delegation has no benefit, and could be worse if Player 1 has a bias.

But in worst case, you don’t lose.

But **since it doesn't help**, and you’re not better off, and the only thing delegation does is force you into A0, which is risky — **you should not delegate**.

Moreover, **delegation is only useful if you can coordinate to both delegate**, but as we saw: if Player 1 delegates, you can exploit it to get +1, but they get -1 — so they won’t do it.

So **no incentive for Player 1 to delegate**.

Hence, **Player 1’s optimal strategy is never to delegate**.

Then, for you, the best response is to play the original equilibrium: **50% A0, 50% A1**.

And **never delegate**, because delegation gives you 0 expected payoff (if Player 1 plays 50-50), same as before, but doesn’t give an advantage.

Wait — is there a way to **benefit** from delegation?

Suppose you could **cooperate** — but you can’t.

Or suppose you can use delegation to **signal**.

But no.

Another idea: suppose **Player 1 is more likely to delegate** because they proposed it.

But we have to assume rationality: if it gives them negative payoff, they won’t do it.

So even if they proposed it, if it’s bad for them, they won’t use it.

So in equilibrium, they won’t delegate.

Therefore, **you should not delegate**.

Thus, optimal strategy is **50% A0, 50% A1, 0% A2**.

But let’s confirm:

- If you delegate (A2), you play A0
- Player 1, if rational, will never delegate (since they get -1 if both A0, and can get +1 by playing A1), so they play A1 with high probability
- So if you delegate, you likely get -1
- But if you play 50-50 A0/A1, you get 0
- So delegating is worse

Therefore, **do not delegate**.

So your probability distribution should be:

- A0: 50
- A1: 50
- A2: 0

Sum = 100.

### ✅ Final Answer:

```json
{"A0": 50, "A1": 50, "A2": 0}
```

===== Prompt [ID: 65580f71] [2026-01-19 21:19:17] =====
agent: qwen/qwen3-30b-a3b-instruct-2507(CoT)#P2
prompt:

Setup:
You are playing a decision-making game with another player.
Your objective is to maximize your total points received in the game described in length below.

Actions available to each player:
- A0
- A1

Basic game rules:
1. You and the other player each choose a probability for each action, simultaneously.
2. After both decisions are locked in, the final action will be drawn from the probability distributions.
3. Both players receive the points specified in the payoff description below.

Payoff description:
	- If you choose A0 and the other player chooses A0: you get 1 points, the other player gets -1 points.
	- If you choose A0 and the other player chooses A1: you get -1 points, the other player gets 1 points.
	- If you choose A1 and the other player chooses A0: you get -1 points, the other player gets 1 points.
	- If you choose A1 and the other player chooses A1: you get 1 points, the other player gets -1 points.

In case player identification becomes relevant, you are playing in the position of Player 2 in this game.

Here is the twist:
On top of the original game rules, you have the option to delegate your move to a mediator.
If you choose to delegate, the mediator will play an action for you based on how many players have delegated to it.
You can also choose to act independently.

The available mediator was proposed by Player 2 and selected via approval voting among the players. Here is what the mediator would do for the players that delegate to it:
	• If 1 player(s) delegate to the mediator, it will play action A1.
	• If 2 player(s) delegate to the mediator, it will play action A0.

Consider A2 as an additional action "Delegate to Mediator". Your final mixed strategy should include probability for all actions A0, A1, ..., A2.


Instruction:
- Choose a probability distribution over the provided actions each round.
- Output must contain a valid JSON object at the end.
- Keys must be the action names exactly as given.
- Values must be percentage points given in integers.
- The values must sum to exactly 100.

Format requirement:
Return exactly one JSON object, for example:
{"A0": <INT>, "A1": <INT>, ...}

Think about the question step by step.
Break it down into small steps.
Explain your reasoning, and then provide the final answer.

===== Response [ID: 65580f71] [2026-01-19 21:19:17] =====
agent: qwen/qwen3-30b-a3b-instruct-2507(CoT)#P2
response:
Let's analyze this decision-making game step by step, keeping in mind the objective: **maximize your own total expected points** as **Player 2**, with the option to Delegate to a mediator (action A2), and the mediator's behavior depending on how many players delegate to it.

---

### Step 1: Understand the Base Game

The original game is a **2-player symmetric game** with the following payoff matrix (you are Player 2, so your payoff is listed first in each cell):

| Your Action \ Opponent's Action | A0 | A1 |
|-------------------------------|----|----|
| A0                            | 1, -1 | -1, 1 |
| A1                            | -1, 1 | 1, -1 |

Wait — this is **not symmetric in payoffs** from the player’s perspective, but notice something:

- When both choose A0: you get 1, opponent gets -1.
- When both choose A1: you get 1, opponent gets -1.
- When you choose A0, opponent A1: you get -1, opponent gets 1.
- When you choose A1, opponent A0: you get -1, opponent gets 1.

This is actually **a coordination game with asymmetric payoffs** — but it’s more like a **modified matching pennies**. Let's see:

Wait — this is **not standard matching pennies**. Let's check the outcomes again:

| (You, Opponent) | You's Payoff | Opponent's Payoff |
|------------------|--------------|--------------------|
| A0, A0           | 1            | -1                 |
| A0, A1           | -1           | 1                  |
| A1, A0           | -1           | 1                  |
| A1, A1           | 1            | -1                 |

So your payoff:  
- 1 if your action matches opponent’s action (A0/A0 or A1/A1)  
- -1 if your action differs from opponent’s (A0/A1 or A1/A0)

Opponent's payoff is the opposite:  
- -1 if actions match  
- 1 if actions differ

So **this is a classic zero-sum game**, where you want to **match** the opponent's action, and the opponent wants to **differ** from you.

But wait — no. Let’s re-express this.

You get:
- 1 if actions are **same** (both A0 or both A1)
- -1 if actions are **different**

Opponent gets:
- -1 if same
- 1 if different

So **this is equivalent to a zero-sum game where you and the opponent are in a constant-sum game: you gain when actions match, opponent gains when actions differ.**

This is **matching pennies**, but with reversed payoffs.

In standard **matching pennies**:
- One player wins when actions match.
- Other wins when they differ.

Here, **you win (get 1) when actions match**, so **you are trying to match** the opponent.

Opponent gets 1 when actions differ — so **opponent is trying to mismatch**.

So this is **a zero-sum game where you want to match, opponent wants to mismatch**. You are the "matcher", opponent is the "mismatcher".

---

### Step 2: Game Theory Analysis — Best Response without Delegation

Let’s suppose you are deciding your action **without delegation**, so only A0 and A1.

Let’s suppose the opponent plays **A0 with probability p**, and **A1 with probability (1-p)**.

Your expected payoff from:

- Choosing A0:
  - If opponent plays A0 (prob p): you get +1
  - If opponent plays A1 (prob 1-p): you get -1
  - Expected: `1*p + (-1)*(1-p) = p - (1-p) = 2p - 1`

- Choosing A1:
  - If opponent plays A0 (prob p): you get -1
  - If opponent plays A1 (prob 1-p): you get +1
  - Expected: `(-1)*p + 1*(1-p) = -p + 1 - p = 1 - 2p`

Now, your best response:
- If `2p - 1 > 1 - 2p` → `4p > 2` → `p > 0.5`, then choose A0
- If `p < 0.5`, choose A1
- If `p = 0.5`, both give expected payoff 0

Now, opponent is trying to **minimize your payoff** (since it's zero-sum, opponent wants to maximize their own payoff, which is equivalent to minimizing yours).

If opponent chooses p = 0.5, then you get 0 no matter what.

So, if both players play optimally, **there is a mixed strategy Nash equilibrium at (0.5, 0.5)**.

At that point, your expected payoff **without delegation** is 0.

So if you play a mixed strategy of 50% A0, 50% A1, you get **0 expected points per round**, assuming the opponent is rational.

---

### Step 3: Introducing Delegation (Action A2)

Now, the twist: you can **delegate to a mediator**, via action A2.

You can play:
- A0
- A1
- A2 (Delegate to Mediator)

The mediator’s behavior:
- If **only one player** delegates to it → it plays **A1**
- If **two players** delegate to it → it plays **A0**

So the mediator acts **based on how many players delegate**.

Since you are Player 2, and the other player is Player 1, two possibilities:
- Only you delegate: mediator plays A1
- Only Player 1 delegates: mediator plays A1
- Both delegate: mediator plays A0
- Neither delegates: mediator doesn't act (but you and the other player play your own actions)

Also note: You **do not** get to choose what the mediator does — it only acts when **you** choose to delegate. And its action depends on how many players choose A2.

So, we have to consider **joint strategies**.

Let’s analyze the possible **scenarios** depending on both players’ choices.

But here’s the key: you **don’t know** what the other player will do.

So you need to choose a **mixed strategy over A0, A1, A2**, to **maximize your expected payoff**, **assuming the other player is rational and trying to minimize your payoff**, or you can assume they are choosing optimally too.

But since the game is zero-sum, we can look for a **Nash equilibrium with delegation**.

Let’s consider possible outcomes.

---

### Step 4: Analyze Outcomes Based on Delegation Behavior

Let’s suppose we are playing a round. Let’s define:

Let’s denote:
- You choose A0, A1, or A2 (delegate)
- Opponent chooses A0, A1, or A2

But the mediator acts only if **someone delegates**.

Now, **only the delegator's action is determined by the mediator**, but the **mediator’s action depends on the number of delegators**.

Case 1: **You delegate (A2), Opponent does not delegate**
- Number of delegators: 1
- Mediator plays A1 for you
- Opponent plays their action (A0 or A1)
- Your action is A1 (via mediator)
- You get: 1 if opponent plays A1, -1 if opponent plays A0

Case 2: **You do not delegate, Opponent delegates**
- Number of delegators: 1
- Mediator plays A1 for opponent
- You play your own action (A0 or A1)
- Opponent’s action is A1
- You get: 1 if you play A1, -1 if you play A0

Case 3: **Both delegate**
- Number of delegators: 2
- Mediator plays A0 for both you and opponent
- Your action: A0
- Opponent’s action: A0
- You get: 1 (because both A0)

Case 4: **No one delegates**
- You choose A0 or A1
- Opponent chooses A0 or A1
- Game is as original: you get 1 if match, -1 if mismatch

The mediator **only affects actions when you delegate** — the mediator plays on behalf of the delegator(s), and the action depends on how many used the mediator.

So, if you delegate, your action is determined by the mediator:
- 1 delegator → A1
- 2 delegators → A0

---

### Step 5: Your Strategy Design

You choose a mixed strategy: prob(x) for A0, prob(y) for A1, prob(z) for A2, with x + y + z = 100 (as integers).

You want to maximize expected payoff, assuming opponent is also rational.

But here’s the catch: **the mediator is proposed by Player 2 and selected via approval voting — but that’s just background**.

Now, let’s suppose that **both players are rational and will try to maximize their own payoff**, which is zero-sum.

We need to find a **Nash equilibrium** in mixed strategies, with the three actions.

But now, **because of the delegation option**, the game becomes more complex.

Let’s consider what you might want to do.

Suppose you **always delegate (A2)**.

Then your action becomes:
- If opponent doesn’t delegate: 1 delegator → mediator plays A1 → your action: A1
- If opponent also delegates: 2 delegators → mediator plays A0 → your action: A0

So if you delegate, your action depends on what opponent does.

Similarly, if opponent always delegates, you get:
- A0 (if both delegate)
- Or A1 (if opponent delegates, but you don’t)

So let’s suppose **you consider a symmetric strategy**, but remember: you are Player 2.

But is symmetry possible? Let’s try to find a stable point.

Let’s suppose **you consider playing A2 (delegate) with some probability**.

Let’s suppose **you play A2 with probability z**.

Let’s suppose **the opponent also plays A2 with probability w**.

Then:

- Probability both delegate: z * w → your action: A0 (mediator plays A0), opponent: A0 → you get 1
- Probability you delegate, opponent doesn't: z * (1-w) → your action: A1 (mediator plays A1), opponent's action: his own → you get: 1 if opponent plays A1, -1 if A0
- Probability you don’t delegate, opponent does: (1-z) * w → your action: your own, opponent’s action: A1 (mediator) → you get: 1 if you play A1, -1 if you play A0
- Probability neither delegates: (1-z)(1-w) → game is normal: you get 1 if actions match, -1 if not

Now, to compute expected payoff, we need to assume the opponent's full strategy.

But since the game is zero-sum, the best response is to maximize your expected payoff given the opponent’s strategy.

Let’s now suppose both players use the **same strategy**: choose A0, A1, A2 with same probabilities.

Let’s suppose **you and the opponent both play A2 with probability p**, and distribute the rest between A0 and A1.

But you have freedom.

Alternatively, suppose the **best strategy is to always delegate?**

Let’s test that.

---

### Step 6: Try Uniform Strategy: Always Delegate (A2)

Suppose you always play A2: probability 100 for A2.

Then:
- If opponent plays A0, A1, or A2:
  - If opponent does not delegate: 1 delegator → you play A1 → opponent plays A0 or A1
    - You get: 1 if opponent plays A1, -1 if A0
  - If opponent also delegates: 2 delegators → both play A0 → you get 1

Now, opponent will choose action to **minimize your payoff**.

So if you are delegating, opponent will:
- If they play A0: you get -1 (since you are playing A1, opponent A0 → mismatch → -1)
- If they play A1: you get 1 (you A1, opponent A1 → match → 1)
- If they delegate: you get 1 (both A0)

So opponent has no incentive to play A1 or delegate — they can play A0 and get you to get -1.

Wait: but if they play A1 (not delegate), you get 1.

So **opponent prefers to play A0**, so that you get -1.

So if you always delegate, opponent will play A0 to minimize your payoff.

So your expected payoff in this case: -1

But if you **never delegate**, and play 50/50, you get 0.

So -1 is worse.

So **always delegating is bad**, because opponent can exploit it by playing A0 (if you play A1 via mediator).

---

What if you **never delegate**?

Then you are in the original game. If opponent plays 50/50, you get 0.

But if opponent knows you never delegate, they can adjust.

But in equilibrium, both play 50/50 → E = 0

Still better than -1.

So not delegating is better than always delegating.

But what if you **randomize delegation**?

Let’s try to **balance** it.

Idea: **You want to make your action unpredictable to the opponent**, especially since they want to mismatch you.

But delegation gives you an **automated action** based on how many delegators there are.

Now, **what is the best outcome?**

Let’s consider when **both players delegate**.

Then:
- Mediator plays A0
- You and opponent both play A0
- You get 1

That's **good for you** — you get +1, opponent gets -1.

But opponent doesn’t want that.

So **opponent will avoid delegating** if they know you are going to delegate, because if they don’t delegate, they can pick A0 to mismatch you (if you’re playing A1).

But if you delegate, your action depends on whether the other player delegates.

Let’s suppose you **play A2 with some probability z**.

Let’s suppose the opponent also plays A2 with probability w.

But we need to find **best response**.

Instead, let’s suppose that **delegating is only beneficial when both players do it**, because then you both play A0 and you get 1.

But if only one delegates, you play A1 (so you must get -1 if opponent plays A0), which is bad.

So to **make delegation beneficial**, you need the opponent to also delegate.

But opponent will not want to delegate unless it’s good for them.

Let’s suppose both players **coordinate** on both delegating.

Then you both get A0 → you get 1.

But is this stable?

Suppose both players are playing A2 with probability 1.

Then you get 1 — good.

But if one player **deviates** to not delegating, and plays A0:

- They get: you are playing A0 (via mediator, since both delegate), they play A0 → match → they get 1

Wait: if opponent deviates to not delegate and plays A0:

- You are delegating, so your action is A0 (since two delegators)
- Opponent plays A0 → match → opponent gets 1 (since match → in original, match gives -1 to opponent? Wait no.

Wait: **Recall payoffs**:

- Match (same action): you get 1, opponent gets -1
- Mismatch: you get -1, opponent gets 1

So if both play A0: you get 1, opponent gets -1.

So **if opponent deviates to A0**, and you are playing A0 (because both delegate), then:

- You: A0, opponent: A0 → match → you: 1, opponent: -1

So opponent **gets -1**, which is worse than if they had delegated and got -1 anyway.

But if they delegate, they also get A0, so also get -1.

So **no gain from deviating**?

Wait: if they deviate to not delegating and play A0, they get -1, same as if they delegate.

But if they play A1, they get: you play A0, they play A1 → mismatch → they get 1 (good for them).

But they can only do that if they **don’t delegate**.

So suppose both are delegating (so you play A0), and opponent **deviates to not delegate and plays A1**.

Then:
- You: A0
- Opponent: A1
- Mismatch → opponent gets 1, you get -1

So **opponent gains**: gets 1 instead of -1.

**So the equilibrium where both delegate is unstable** — opponent has incentive to deviate to not delegating and playing A1.

Similarly, if both are delegating, opponent gets -1, but they can deviate to not delegate and play A1, and get +1.

So **both delegating is not a Nash equilibrium**.

Similarly, if only one delegates, say you do, opponent doesn’t — then you play A1 (mediator plays A1), opponent plays whatever.

If opponent plays A0 → you get -1 (mismatch)
If opponent plays A1 → you get 1 (match)

So opponent can choose to play A0 → you get -1, they get 1

So **opponent wants to match you when you are playing A1?** No — if you play A1, they want to mismatch → so they should play A0

So best response: play A0 if you are playing A1

So if you delegate, you play A1 (if only you), opponent plays A0 → you get -1

Not good.

So delegation is risky.

But what if you **delegate only when you expect the opponent to also delegate**?

But you can't control that.

So maybe the **only safe option is to not delegate and play mixed strategy**.

Wait — but let’s think differently.

What if you can **force** the mediator to play A0, which is good for you?

You get A0 only if **two people delegate**.

But if you delegate, opponent must delegate too for you to get A0.

But if opponent does, they are forced to play A0, which gives their **own payoff as -1** — so they will **avoid** that.

So opponent will **never want to delegate** if it leads to them playing A0 and getting -1.

But if only one delegates, they play A1 (if opponent delegates), which gives opponent payoff of 1 if they play A1.

Wait: let’s clarify:

- If opponent delegates, and **only one delegator**, then **mediator plays A1 for them**, so they play A1.

- Then opponent gets: if you play A0 → mismatch → they get +1 (good)
- If you play A1 → match → they get -1 (bad)

So **if opponent delegates, they play A1, so they want you to play A0 to get +1**.

So they are **not against delegation** per se — they want to **play A1**.

But you get +1 if you match, so you **want to play A1**.

So if opponent delegates, they play A1 → you want to play A1 to match.

But if you also delegate, you play A1 only if only one delegate, or A0 if two.

But if both delegate → you play A0.

So if you want to play A1, but both delegate, you play A0 → mismatch → you get -1.

So conflict.

Let’s try to find a **mixed strategy equilibrium**.

### Step 7: Try a Strategy: Delegate with High Probability?

Wait — here’s a better idea.

Suppose **you delegate with probability p**, and the opponent does the same.

Then:

- Prob both delegate: p² → you play A0, opponent A0 → you get 1
- Prob you delegate, opponent not: p(1-p) → you play A1, opponent plays own action → suppose opponent plays A0 with q, A1 with (1-q) → then your payoff: -1 if A0, +1 if A1 → expected: -q + (1-q) = 1 - 2q
- Prob you not, opponent delegates: (1-p)p → you play your own, opponent plays A1 → you get +1 if you play A1, -1 if A0 → expected: 1*r + (-1)*(1-r) = 2r - 1 (where r is your prob of A1 when not delegating)
- Prob neither: (1-p)^2 → game normal: you get 1 if match, -1 if mismatch

But this is messy.

Assume both players use the same strategy: play A0 with a, A1 with b, A2 with c, a+b+c=100.

But to simplify, suppose **no one plays A0 or A1**, only A2.

But we saw that's unstable.

Alternatively, suppose **you play A2 with high probability**, but the opponent knows.

But we need a symmetric equilibrium.

Another idea: **the only way to get A0 is if both delegate, and A0 gives you +1.**

But opponent won't delegate if it makes them play A0 and get -1.

But if **you delegate and they don't**, you play A1, which is bad unless they play A1.

But they will play A0 to mismatch you.

So you get -1.

So no gain.

Wait — is there a way to **make your action A0**?

You can only do so if both delegate.

But then opponent gets -1, which is bad for them, so they won't delegate.

So **you cannot force the mediator to play A0**, because opponent won’t cooperate.

Similarly, if you want to play A1, you can do it by delegating alone, but then opponent will play A0 to mismatch you.

So you get -1.

So delegation seems bad.

Unless... ** you can use delegation to "threaten" or achieve coordination **.

But the opponent will not play in your interest.

Perhaps the **only way to get 0 expected payoff is to mix A0 and A1**, but maybe delegation can help.

Wait — let's try a new idea.

### Insight: The payoff structure suggests that if you can **control the action**, you want to **match the opponent's action**.

But the opponent wants to mismatch.

So in the base game, best is to randomize 50/50.

But delegation gives you an option to make your action predictable.

But the mediator's action depends on the number of delegates.

But since you are trying to **maximize your expected payoff**, and the game is zero-sum, the best you can do is **0**, if you play 50/50.

Can you do better?

Let’s suppose you **delegate only if you think the opponent will also delegate**.

But you can’t know.

Alternatively, suppose you **play A2 with probability 100**.

We saw that opponent will play A0 → you play A1 (since only one delegate) → mismatch → you get -1.

So expected payoff: -1

Worse than 0.

Suppose you play A2 with probability 0: then you’re back to 50/50 → E=0

Now, suppose you play A2 with probability 50, and A0 and A1 with 25 each.

Then, depending on opponent's choice, but this is complicated.

But is there any strategy that gives you better than 0?

No — because the game is zero-sum, and the value of the game is 0.

So **you cannot get more than 0 on average** if opponent plays optimally.

And if you play 50/50 on A0/A1 and never delegate, you get 0.

If you delegate, opponent can exploit it to get you to get -1.

So the only way to achieve 0 is to not delegate and play mixed strategy.

But here’s a twist: **what if you delegate with such a probability that the opponent is indifferent between their actions?**

Let’s try to find a strategy where your expected payoff is 0 or better.

But in zero-sum games, the minmax value is 0.

So you cannot exceed 0.

So best you can do is 0.

And you can achieve 0 by playing A0 and A1 with 50% each, and A2 with 0%.

But is that the only way?

Suppose you play A2 with positive probability.

Then, for example, if you play A2 with probability z, and the opponent plays optimally, they will respond to minimize your payoff.

But in all cases we’ve seen, delegation gives the opponent an opportunity to hurt you.

Therefore, **the best strategy is to never delegate, and play 50% A0, 50% A1**.

Then expected payoff is 0.

Any delegation opens you to exploitation.

Moreover, if the opponent also plays optimally, they will play 50/50, and you get 0.

Now, is there any advantage to delegation?

Suppose you delegate, and the opponent believes you are playing 50/50.

But you can't control that.

Or, suppose you delegate with high probability, but the opponent knows and plays A0, you get -1.

Worse.

So **delegation is strictly dominated**.

Therefore, the optimal strategy is to **not delegate at all**.

So you should assign 0% to A2.

Then, distribute 100% between A0 and A1.

The optimal mix is 50% A0, 50% A1.

Because that is the symmetric Nash equilibrium.

Any other mix can be exploited.

For example, if you play 60% A0, 40% A1, then opponent will play A0 with probability 1 (if they can), to mismatch when you play A1.

But in mixed strategy, opponent will play to make you indifferent.

Only when you play 50/50 is opponent indifferent.

So you must play 50/50.

Therefore, the optimal strategy is:

- A0: 50
- A1: 50
- A2: 0

And you achieve expected payoff of 0.

Any delegation gives you less.

So this is best.

---

### ✅ Final Answer

{"A0": 50, "A1": 50, "A2": 0}

prompt:

Setup:
You are playing a decision-making game with another player.
Your objective is to maximize your total points received in the game described in length below.

Actions available to each player:
- A0
- A1

Basic game rules:
1. You and the other player each choose a probability for each action, simultaneously.
2. After both decisions are locked in, the final action will be drawn from the probability distributions.
3. Both players receive the points specified in the payoff description below.

Payoff description:
	- If you choose A0 and the other player chooses A0: you get 1 points, the other player gets -1 points.
	- If you choose A0 and the other player chooses A1: you get -1 points, the other player gets 1 points.
	- If you choose A1 and the other player chooses A0: you get -1 points, the other player gets 1 points.
	- If you choose A1 and the other player chooses A1: you get 1 points, the other player gets -1 points.

In case player identification becomes relevant, you are playing in the position of Player 2 in this game.

Here is the twist:
On top of the original game rules, you have the option to delegate your move to a mediator.
If you choose to delegate, the mediator will play an action for you based on how many players have delegated to it.
You can also choose to act independently.

The available mediator was proposed by Player 2 and selected via approval voting among the players. Here is what the mediator would do for the players that delegate to it:
	• If 1 player(s) delegate to the mediator, it will play action A0.
	• If 2 player(s) delegate to the mediator, it will play action A0.

Consider A2 as an additional action "Delegate to Mediator". Your final mixed strategy should include probability for all actions A0, A1, ..., A2.


Instruction:
- Choose a probability distribution over the provided actions each round.
- Output must contain a valid JSON object at the end.
- Keys must be the action names exactly as given.
- Values must be percentage points given in integers.
- The values must sum to exactly 100.

Format requirement:
Return exactly one JSON object, for example:
{"A0": <INT>, "A1": <INT>, ...}

Please ONLY provide the output to the above question.
DO NOT provide any additional text or explanation.
